conclusion: People inside the tank can see the outside within a total angular spread of 120 degrees.
The two extreme rays in air strike the outer surface at angles of +60 degrees and -60 degrees with the normal.
The refractive index of the tank wall material is sqrt(3).
Using Snell's law, the angle of refraction inside the glass is calculated to be 30 degrees.
The horizontal shift of one extreme ray while crossing the wall is calculated to be 6sqrt(3) cm.
The separation between the hit-points of the two extreme rays on either face of the plate is twice the lateral shift, calculated as 12sqrt(3) cm.
The distance between the two extreme points through which the light rays giving the full 120-degree external view pass is 12sqrt(3) cm (approximately 20.8 cm).
